image.altText: A man in a green puffer jacket stands outside a Catholic church holding an old photo of a priest

items.synopsis: Brendan Watkins is one of thousands of children of Catholic priests who found their biological parents through DNA testing and social media. His birth wasn't the only secret his father kept.

title.children: ‘I found your mother. She’s a nun’ — and 30 years later Brendan discovered his father was a priest

image.altText: A man and woman smile for the camera.

items.synopsis: Ian Wilkinson's family says he remains in a critical but stable condition, and have thanked medical teams and the public for their support.

title.children: Family of man ill from suspected mushroom poisoning says he remains 'critical but stable'

image.altText: Scott Brunton with a horse in a stable.

items.synopsis: One of Tasmania's largest thoroughbred training stables says it is "stunned" to be put into administration, saying a five-year payment plan totalling about $1 million was rejected by the ATO.

title.children: 'We are stunned': Top Tasmanian thoroughbred stable goes into administration owing tax office

image.altText: a female soccer player high fives a young fan at sydney airport

items.synopsis: Stadiums at Moore Park and Parramatta will open as additional live sites on Wednesday, as Matildas captain Sam Kerr tells reporters at Sydney Airport the side had not celebrated their win.

title.children: Matildas in Sydney ahead of semifinal clash as stadiums added to list of live sites

image.altText: Matildas celebrate on field wave to crowd

items.synopsis: More than four million Australians tuned in to see the Matildas beat France in the World Cup quarterfinals.

title.children: Matildas v France World Cup match pulls the biggest TV audience of 2023

image.altText: a black and white photo of a young woman showing her pregnancy bump, looking at the camera

items.synopsis: Documentary photographer Ricky Maynard says trust and conversation is key to the art of portraiture.

title.children: Thirty years ago Ricky went inside prisons to capture the faces of Indigenous incarceration. He never forgot them

image.altText: Silhouette of the statue of an Aboriginal hunter holding a spear and looking over the town of Roebourne from the top of a hill

items.synopsis: A landmark court case is hearing whether traditional owners have a right to compensation from Andrew Forrest's FMG, but experts say far more than their own claim is on trial.

title.children: Sadness, anger as billionaire miner's legal battle with the Yindjibarndi puts native title rights on trial

image.altText: Greg Stewart with rail bug

items.synopsis: The railway group volunteer has built a set of rail bugs from scratch, hoping they provide a lifeline for his railway group.

title.children: Greg's pedal-powered plan to get tourism back on track in Tasmania's north-east

image.altText: A metal device used in ATM card scam

items.synopsis: Police were alerted to the alleged card skimming scam by investigators in the United States who found a receipt for a shipment sent to an address in Australia.

title.children: US Secret Service tip-off leads to arrest of five foreign nationals over alleged ATM scam

image.altText: Lyz Evans talking to a pregnant client who is lying on a medical bed.

items.synopsis: Every year, more than 300,000 Australians take part in a physical activity than can result in long-term, life-altering physical injuries: childbirth.

title.children: Pelvic injuries are a common outcome of childbirth. Why are women left unprepared for the risk?

image.altText: Cortnee Vine kicks the winning penalty against France at the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: Coming off the bench in the 104th minute of the Matildas' Women's World Cup quarterfinal against France, the 25-year-old had little idea she was about to write her name into Australian sporting folklore.

title.children: How Cortnee Vine showed nerves of steel to send Matildas through to World Cup semis

image.altText: A man in suit surrounded by crowds.

items.synopsis: China's Foreign Ministry condemns a brief US visit by Taiwan Vice President William Lai, saying he is a separatist and "troublemaker through and through" and Beijing would take strong steps to protect its sovereignty.

title.children: China vows 'resolute and vigorous’ response to US visit by Taiwan vice president

image.altText: Philip Lowe and Michele Bullock August 2023

items.synopsis: After more than 40 years as a central banker, RBA governor Philip Lowe says we should consider different ways of managing inflation, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: RBA governor Philip Lowe says there could be better ways to manage inflation

image.altText: A sign prohibiting unmanned aerial vehicles flying over the area is on display near the Kremlin wall.

items.synopsis: Suspected Ukrainian drone strikes in Moscow are increasing with analysts saying mass attacks are likely. But questions remain around what Kyiv hopes to achieve and whether there will even be much impact.

title.children: Drone strikes on Moscow are ramping up with signs a 'truly massive' attack may not be far off

image.altText: A person standing outside P.O. boxes in a regional community.

items.synopsis: Residents of a rapidly growing area near one of Victoria's biggest cities are being asked to vote for or against street mail delivery in Australia Post's third ballot on the issue in six years.

title.children: When Lisa built her new home, she assumed it came with a mailing address. She was wrong

image.altText: A woman with blue eyes and long dark hair looks off camera with a serious expression

items.synopsis: An access road left unfinished in the wake of a building company collapse stood in the way of 20 homes being built — now, the South Australian government has stepped in to finish it.

title.children: 'A light at the end of the tunnel': State government steps in after building company collapse

image.altText: Three post it notes in blue, white and yellow, with questions about sex and puberty written on them in messy handwriting.

items.synopsis: Young people's curiosity about sex is nothing new, but access to the internet and the terabytes of graphic pornography it hosts has given rise to a fresh set of concerns: if kids go looking for answers to their awkward questions on Google, what will they find?

title.children: The anonymous question a sex educator hears from kids nearly every day

image.altText: A road winds through blackened trees and flattened buildings.

items.synopsis: As the road to Lahaina was reopened on the fire-devastated Hawaiian island of Maui, residents hoped against hope that something would be left of their homes. They discovered a blackened hellscape.

title.children: In pictures: Inside the Maui town obliterated by a firestorm

image.altText: An aerial photo showing a town where all the buildings have been destroyed by fire.

items.synopsis: The increased death toll makes the wildfire, which erupted on Tuesday, Hawaii's worst natural disaster in history.

title.children: Death toll reaches 93 in Maui after the deadliest US wildfire in more than a century

image.altText: Chris Hipkins addressing a press conference.

items.synopsis: Chris Hipkins announced the Labour Party would take the GST off of fruit and vegetables if his party was re-elected.

title.children: NZ prime minister says GST will be taken off fruit and vegetables if Labour Party is re-elected

items.synopsis: Ricky Stuart laments 'a really, really embarrassing performance' from the Raiders, as the Knights count the cost of their thumping of the Bulldogs. Get your full Sunday NRL wrap here.

title.children: NRL wrap: Raiders 'embarrassing' in Storm loss as Knights lose star to nasty ankle injury

image.altText: Australia players run to celebrate after winning a Women's WOrld Cup quarterfinal against France.

items.synopsis: When someone asks you to tell the story of the night the Matildas made history, what will you say?

title.children: Matildas' World Cup win over France was the game that stopped a nation

image.altText: A young, laughing girl is mid-air as she plays in the river with a man, another child's head can be seen in the water

items.synopsis: The Amazon's rivers are under increasing threat from the expansion of agriculture and illegal deforestation, but one municipality has passed a groundbreaking law designating a waterway as a living entity with rights.

title.children: Indigenous leader inspires Amazon city to grant personhood to endangered river

image.altText: Several people stand around looking at various items laid out on the ground.

items.synopsis: A flea market in the Ukrainian capital draws in hundreds of people, where people can buy various Soviet-era items.

title.children: Flea market in Ukraine's capital still draws in crowd, amid ongoing conflict

image.altText: A pile of peso banknotes with Star Wars characters painted on them.

items.synopsis: How did a country, once among the wealthiest in the world and uncomfortably similar to Australia, totally lose control of its economy?

title.children: Worthless banknotes and spending money while you have it: This is what life is like with 100pc inflation

image.altText: A composite of photos of Abbie smiling

items.synopsis: Abbie Williams learnt the art of painting a smile over despair during some of her darkest hours, but it was pen and paper that helped define her recovery, a gift since shared with more than 2,500 people.

title.children: Abbie hid her depression behind a smile, until her Letters of Hope sparked real joy

image.altText: A woman wearing a colourful dress and hijab wipes tears from her eyes.

items.synopsis: Khadidja is one of thousands of refugees who fled Sudan after a bloody civil war broke out between the army and a paramilitary group. Now she’s stuck inside one of the worst humanitarian crises on earth.

title.children: Khadidja lost her husband and her home. Now she's stuck inside one of the worst humanitarian disasters on Earth

image.altText: Women walk down a street holding umbrellas.

items.synopsis: The UN human rights office expresses grave concern over the forced repatriation of North Koreans from China and elsewhere after facing criticism from rights groups for its "unacceptable silence" on the issue.

title.children: 'Blatant, casual politicisation': UN human rights office accused of 'unacceptable silence' over forced repatriation of North Koreans

image.altText: Both the doll and the box for Allan, Ken doll's friend.

items.synopsis: Collectors say the Barbie movie has sparked new fans of the dolls and there's one that "everyone wants in their collection".

title.children: The Barbie you may never have heard of is the hottest new doll in town

image.altText: Ryan Gosling as Ken with bleached blonde hair and a denim shirt showcasing his abs

items.synopsis: If Barbie has taught us anything, it's that women can do anything. But an increasing number of people are saying young men and boys are now crying out for role models on how to be the best version of themselves.

title.children: It's not just Ken — why are boys and men feeling out in the cold?

image.altText: Goat with horns, long hair, laying on the sand on a beach, on a sunny day, blue sky, sea in the distance, hills with greenery.

items.synopsis: Benji the goat loves to go to the beach with his best mate, Boson, the dog, followed by morning tea at a nearby cafe. The affectionate animal brings joy to the community.

title.children: The beach-loving pet goat that's capturing hearts

image.altText: The face of a young man, who is holding a vape, is covered in vape smoke

items.synopsis: We need to know more about exactly what is inside vapes and e-cigarettes and how people use them so we can better understand and quantify the health risks in the real world, writes Alexander Larcombe.

title.children: Even experts don't know exactly what's in vapes. But the radioactive metal Russia uses to kill dissenters is on the list

image.altText: Dainty green tree frog with an inflated vocal sac under its chin

items.synopsis: Animals can make the strangest sounds. Tune into the noises made by some iconic species and find out how they make them.

title.children: Fish farts, snorting koalas, bonking frogs: How do animals make these crazy sounds?

image.altText: Utzon thumbnail 3

items.synopsis: It's one of the greatest buildings of the 20th century. Fifty years after the Sydney Opera House opened its doors, we look at how this bold experiment has shaped Australia.

title.children: He created one of the greatest buildings of the 20th century. Why did Jørn Utzon walk away?
